newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada's Goodale to rely on suasion to move grain.
newsitem.headline: Canada's Goodale to rely on suasion to move grain.

text.p: Canadian Agriculture Minister Ralph Goodale said on Tuesday he would have to rely mainly on his powers of persuasion to convince Canada's rail companies to move more grain more quickly.

He was reacting to a request by the Canadian Wheat Board to intervene in a situation where delayed rail shipments of grain led to more than 34 ships waiting to load on the Pacific, possibly causing demurrage fees of C$15 million.
"The options for direct intervention are certainly limited," Goodale told Reuters.

"I have already had conversations with railway representatives and I intend to continue to pursue that...I want to follow those up to see what they're prepared to do to alleviate the situation in the shortest time period possible."

Asked if legislation could be introduced to rectify the situation if it persisted, he said he would be willing to take a look at it. But he said these options were limited and that he would have to discuss it with cabinet colleagues before making any detailed comment.
The main problem, he said, was the need for more locomotive power.
He said a factor in the delays was cold and snow, but that every Canadian January had such conditions and that the CWB thought there was a problem in the system.
